abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Multi-Sectoral
            STI/HIV/AIDS (Sexually Transmitted Infections/Human Immune
            Deficiency Virus/Acquired Immune-Deficiency Syndrome)
            Support Project for Niger were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was substantial, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: fighting and
            preventing HIV/AIDS is fundamental to the economic and
            social development of a country. Therefore, regardless of
            income level, governments should not rely only on donor
            resources which are characterized by unpredictability and
            uncertainty. It is necessary to clarify the institutional
            setting at the design stage to avoid dual oversight and to
            make sure that only one structure is accountable for project
            execution. Technical assistance for project execution and
            monitoring and evaluation (M&E) should be embedded in
            this type of project, especially when national capacities
            are known to be weak. The technical assistance package
            should be flexible enough so that it can be redeployed to
            help address emerging challenges, as the implementation
            unfolds. For instance, technical assistance for M&E is
            essential to fine tune results framework, collect data,
            compare them and use them to better inform policies and
            strategies. The success of complex, multi-sectoral HIV/AIDS
            projects in very low capacity environments is likely to be
            due to the commitment and competence of one or a few
            exceptional individuals. Since such individuals are
            typically few and far between, it makes such projects very
            risky. Furthermore, since the Bank has no mechanism to
            ensure that such individuals are found and hired, it is
            difficult to see how appropriate mitigation measures can be developed.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa - Multi-Country HIV/AIDS Program for
            Africa (MAP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The umbrella restructuring for the
            Sub-Saharan Multi Country HIV/AIDS Program would eliminate
            prevalence as a development objective indicator and refocus
            new objectives towards HIV/AIDS prevention, care/treatment
            and mitigation interventions at the country level. National
            responses would focus on improving monitoring and evaluation
            capacity, realigning indicators to national strategies,
            funding priority interventions as well as setting-up better
            coordinated institutional arrangements. Several projects are
            to be presented to the board separately, these projects and
            their descriptions are provided in this report.

5085817.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is part of a multi-country
            HIV/AIDS Program in Africa, through which this operation
            aims at strengthening preventive measures so as to slow the
            spread of HIV/AIDS, and at expanding support, and care for
            those infected, or affected by the epidemic. Through a
            multi-sectoral approach, the project objectives will support
            the implementation of Niger's Strategic Framework for
            the Fight against STIs/HIV/AIDS for the period 2002-2007.
            The development objective of both the National Program, and
            this operation are to slow the spread of HIV/AIDS, mitigate
            the adverse impacts of the disease, and, strengthen capacity
            to formulate, manage, implement, monitor and evaluate a
            cost-effective HIV/AIDS program, attained through a
            multi-sectoral approach, drawing on comparative advantages,
            and partnerships among both public, and private entities.
            Within its components, the project will support strategic
            orientations to scale up, expand, and improve prevention
            activities, through the treatment, and care of local
            populations, and activities to mitigate the impoverishment
            effects of the epidemic, as well as strengthen the national
            capacity to implement the multi-sectoral HIV/AIDS program.
            To this end, prevention, care, and mitigation activities
            will be financed through line Ministries, to attain a strong
            health system (that includes tuberculosis prevention, and
            care), through the provision of education, training, and
            improved access to treatment, intensified by the civil
            society response, and community-based initiatives. Capacity
            building and further training activities for the public
            sector, and civil society agencies should foster effective
            management of preventive, and treatment activities. Project
            management activities will support technical assistance,
            program coordination, and administration, and, facilitate
            the multi-country AIDS program's strategic management.

repnme.cdata!:
Niger - HIV/AIDS Prevention and Care
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            HIV/AIDS Prevention and Care Project is mainly concerned
            with reducing the risk of infection posed by biomedical
            waste collection, storage, and disposal in connection with
            this project. The two types of waste health care facilities
            would produce are solid waste such as that produced by
            health care providers diagnosing and treating patients as
            well as ordinary garbage, and liquid waste derived from
            blood and toxic/hazardous chemicals, along with laboratory
            research and pharmaceutical waste products, and waste
            products resulting from surgery, for example, anatomical
            waste, disinfectants, mercury compounds, x-ray films,
            syringes, tubes, other instruments, and used bandages. Solid
            waste comprises the main category of wastes that poses the
            risk of transmission of Hepatitis B or C and/or HIV/AIDS,
            especially through sharps, syringes, and other cutting
            instruments, and is the main focus of this assessment. The
            report also identifies the risk of air pollution due to the
            release of hydrochloric acid, and silver and sulfuric oxides
            as well as carcinogenic particle emissions. Incinerating
            plastic also raises the risk of toxic gas release. Surface
            and underground water could be polluted by runoff from these
            biomedical wastes. Measures to mitigate the risk of
            contamination include: Building the institutional capacity
            of hospitals, health centers, and health agencies; equipping
            health facilities and personnel involved in waste disposal
            with protective gear (masks and gowns) and equipment;
            providing health facilities with suitable collection bins
            for storing biomedical waste; providing disinfectant
            (bleach) to sterilize needles and "sharps"
            (instruments); and providing health facilities with mobile
            equipment (carts and wheelbarrows) to aid in removing waste;
            and building incinerators. Waste management activities will
            involve the private sector and members of civil society.
            Efforts will be made to disseminate information through the
            media, and to train personnel and others exposed to
            infectious diseases.

Niger - HIV/AIDS Prevention and Care Project
